review_title: You work here for the benefits. Other than that, it’s a decent job.

The staff is mostly permanent and have been working for several years in the company. Low staff rotation.
cons: - Being a franchise, most of the great policies of Marriott for employees, structure, training, career path, etc, are not accomplished. - Lack of leadership - Almost no posibilities to grow inside the company.

pros: This is a beautiful hotel with great opportunities to make money, specially because our restaurant is not owned by Marriott we constantly have events that bring in revenue.

I've been working for this company for one year and I can contest that I am the only employee that has made it this long, which is saying a lot. I've gone through 4 GMs and 2 AGM's, I am on my 3rd. It seems like every time a new manager is hired once the hotel/restaurant is about to have some sort of structure the top management works our bosses to ground and don't offer any sort of incentive to keep them. They rather just hire a new manager and have their staff at square one. Its really disappointing.

review_title: This job is not for introverts or sensitive ppl
pros: Work from home Managers are okay Downtime is available sometimes if there not enough calls You are able to go to the bathroom After 90 days you can request earlier shifts
cons: - The pay and what you deal with don’t match up -The software they use is outdated ,doesn’t alway work which means you lose sales -No pay after 4hrs if your having tech issues -training and actually on the calls do not match -you are given a discount to stay at properties however I found customers using the discount more than me - you can move up quickly however all customer service jobs remotely require you be on the phone including chat.Depending on the position will determine how often -The metrics are unrealistic. They want you to help the guest but control the call and do this under 10 minutes.and make a sale aka reservation - the guest can be rude and very entitled.You deal with this more with the higher tier members - No tech team.if a guest calls about app or websites issue you have to help them even though you was not train nor are tech savvy -back to back calls -taking days off is a struggle. They have a calendar and it tells you which days you can request or not -they do not acknowledge mental heath days -your not allow to have 2 days off in a row or take full weekends off.

job_title: Room Inspector Hotel in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Team Work Makes The Dream Work all the way around....

pros:
Travel benefits are great, although getting steep discounts on hotel rooms has gotten a lot harder post-Covid. 
There's lots of areas to progress into and even try your hand out at things you never thought you'd be doing.
I have a bachelor's degree that's not in hospitality or even in business, but they really only care that I have a degree, not what's its in. That's been really nice because I've been able to take a job that was supposed to be temporary and make it a career.
cons:
The company has made a lot of changes over the last 3 years with the merger with Starwood and the changes continue daily. Sometimes it's hard to keep up with who reports to whom and who owns what. I feel like every week there's a new VP hired of a department I never knew existed (or didn't exist before this person was hired), but I feel like they're filling more VP positions and need to be working out the kinks waaaaay below that level. There's a lack of oversight in places and those places are hurting us. 
Communication can always be better between departments for changes that affect others.
Pay can always be better.
I do think they've lost sight of the Mr. Marriott quote that says "If you take care of your associates, your associates will take care of the guest and the guest will keep coming back". 2017 and 2018 forced a LOT of new technology that was broken down associates throats and has yet to fix it (its 2022)...

Internal transferring is highly encouraged and not hard to accomplish if the above is achieved. Benefits are good/standard and as to be expected for this type of company.

review_title: Marriott preaches values it can't uphold
pros: Good job stability- as they rarely fire anyone. Somewhat decent discounts at hotels, but you can rarely find a room for more than a couple of nights consecutively.
cons: Work with lots of inept people, especially management. Poor training all around. Forced to take breaks while working, tantamount to wage theft. Corporate does not understand working as an hourly employee, especially a server or bartender, and we are forced to take mandatory breaks or be made to stay after our shifts, or come in earlier to take an unpaid break. People across all departments describe working through unpaid breaks, all done under the guise of Marriott "caring" about each employee so that they have time to eat/ use the restroom, etc, but this is not what actually happens as there is frequently no coverage. A "working break" is supposed to be paid.

job_title: Food and Beverage Associate in Glasgow, Scotland
pros: If you're allowed the time to enjoy the benefits, they are quite good. A strong team feeling amongst the floor staff.
cons:
Senior Management and HR are far too close meaning there is no way of HR remaining a neutral party when issues arise.  There exists a 2-tier system of associates where 'upstairs' office workers are allowed to do things that the 'downstairs' floor workers would be reprimanded for.  This also contributes to an attitude from the office workers that their fellow associates are below them simply because they work in a front of house role.  It is also a major factor in creating the nasty and toxic work environment that trickles down from senior management.  People are promoted far too quickly and often left with minimal training to figure out entirely different job roles as they work. 
 The company tried to engage in "Fire and Re-Hire" during Covid-19 but are still left with a skill shortage as people moved on to different industries.

pros:
Benefits (after 90 days) 
Manager was nice
Staff and other agents friendly
cons:
For me it was an overall okay but not great experience.  I've worked for customer service for many years and this job was the most stressful out of all of them. I trained for a month, had a family emergency come up, and was told I would have to start my training all over again. I wouldn't have minded if I was one or two weeks in; but I was there for almost the full month and I would have to restart. But I think what made it an overall not good experience is the job wasn't worth the pay that they're giving you. Also having to work crazy hours until midnight doesn't help. If you wanted to change your hours you had to wait at least 90 days before than. On top of that having to wait 90 days before your benefits kicked in didn't help. I'm new to the state that I'm in and brought my own insurance until my job insurance came in. 
$15 an hour is nice until your bills start to add up and other employer's are hiring at a better rate. I learned this the hard way and to anyone who reads this know your worth because I'm not worth $15 and this job isn't worth it either.

Not worth the stress or mental headache

review_title: Leadership's priorities don't align with their slogan
pros:
Resort and Hotel discounts
Opportunity to work OT when offered
Bi-weekly income
cons:
Leadership doesn't align with the company's slogan: take care of your employees, they'll take care of your customers and the customers will keep coming back again and again.

It doesn't seem like the employees are well-taken care of with such low wages.

They do not offer night differential pay.

They offer discount hotel resort rates on your first hire date, yet they don't provide medical/dental benefits until 90 days later.

High turnover (especially in the call center department)

The tech support has poor follow-up skills. They close out tickets and enter them as tasks completed when the issue is pending.

They need to revamp the recruiting team so they can hire quality candidates, especially in the call center department.

The biggest slap in the face is that they pride themselves on continually opening new hotels, which you have to read about daily, and multi million dollar renovations, but they can’t pay their employees a living wage. job_title: Night Auditor/Front Desk Agent in Covington, LA
pros: Not a very hard job to do, not labor intensive, sometimes (VERY RARELY) the employee discounts are worth it.
cons:
Employee discounts are only available sometimes and even then you will be paying more than regular rates and government rates so most often the employee discount is not worth it. 

The company decided to let each owner decide if they would charge their employees for a mishap on their auditing part due to a server infiltration. They decided that most of us owe around $5,000 or more without proving this to us nor looking into the proof we had that we in fact did not owe that amount and yet they still took payments out of our checks without even discussing any of this to us. 

Management is lacking severely and training is on your own to figure out.

There are no opportunities to grow within the company unless you move to another city.

review_title: Exceptional leadership, but now very corporate
pros: Conservative company.  Great for stability and growth.   The best part about this company was their exceptional leadership and peer support.  Everyone was very supportive in doing everything possible and within their power to help you move "up" within the company.  There's endless training and their whole M-O is to keep you in the company, working for them.
cons: Very corporate.  I would hear "veteran" employees discuss how this wasn't the company they started with.   It's a long ladder to climb and seniority pay/benefits will take time.  Great experience, but feels like a dated company.  Needs more remote positions and modern appeal.

pros: Tepid employee discounts at Marriott properties. Decent 401k match.
cons: They like to repeat ad nauseam how much they value and want to preserve the company culture, but the so-called culture they keep talking about does not exist. They're forcing staff back into the new headquarters to justify all the money they spent on their new "fancy" downtown building, while the rest of our benefits shrink even though the return-to-office ship has already sailed. Laughable paid-time-off and company holidays. Incredibly bureaucratic inner-workings. No continuing-education reimbursement or initiatives. Flex schedule? Forget about it. No upward mobility for anyone who isn't already at the director level. Virtually nonexistent diversity and inclusion programs that aren't front-facing publicity stunts. I could keep going, but I don't think there is enough space here. Marriott is still operating like it's 1991.

It was very greasy, but it was the safest and fastest way to get in the building. Better Pat would attract higher quality people and encourage them to work hard to keep their jobs. Low pay decreased morale and people care less if they lose their job. It was okay pay for a starter job. In hindsight, my work hours exceeded the legal limit for a high school student. I was given too many hours late at night and my grades suffered. No one ever asked my age or if I needed to go home before midnight. I had to call several times for a start date after I was hired. The manager kept “forgetting.” It was strange. I started about 6 weeks after being hired.

pros: They make an honest effort to prepare their workers for the job, They provided new equipment that was simple to use. A desktop, Wi-Fi phone, headsets, ethernet cords. GREAT discounts on hotel rooms.
cons: 1. No Communication From Management PART A: You are expected to work EVERY holiday. No taking turns, not every other holiday, EVERY holiday The trainers claimed that this was explained upon hire. This was NOT explained upon hire. They kept repeating this lie even though EVERY associate in the hiring group agreed this was not mentioned upon hire. If you want a day off you have to compete with every single person, because the standard schedules are not honored during the holidays. The bidding for holidays is largely decided by seniority. That means they get every holiday off and you get nothing. I should at least be able to get ONE holiday off. In the first 90 days you don't even get bonus pay. How are you going to make me miss Christmas and Thanksgiving with my family and then disqualify me from holiday pay? If you don't live near your family then you have to give up on every seeing them. PART B: The first time I spoke to my manager was when I was resigning. I was there for a month and I had to repeatedly ask to get the name and email of my manager. By the time I got their name I was already ready to resign. There was no one to answer my questions. HR did not respond to my emails and my the trainers use all their time on the 5 people who need instructions on how to screw in a lightbulb. 2. Unprofessional coworkers/trainers Lots of gossip and meanspirited comments towards people not in the meeting rooms. I have NEVER reported anything to HR in my professional career. I considered doing it TWICE in the month I worked here. I mentioned the unprofessional environment as a reason for resignation. HR and management had ZERO interest in knowing what I was talking about. List of some minor and major things I witnessed. REALLLY distasteful statements made about the trainers and the workers not in the conference call. That I will not repeat because then this review would not get posted. A worker INSULTING and BERATING a coworker in a call with everyone in it. This was not interrupted or called out for being inappropriate. I would have fired this person on the spot. If I hadn't left the next day I would have reported them to HR and the trainers for allowing this person to bully their classmate. Individual talking about her sex life and how she hadn't gotten laid in 7 years in a work call with 20 people WHILE she was in office where management could hear. People chewing into microphones and not muting themselves. The trainers did not directly address this person they just made passive aggressive comments.

Training is ridiculous. You are basically paid to sit and do nothing for 4 weeks. Amazing way of making money for nothing.
cons:
Their system is shockingly bad. Freezes constantly, doesn’t allow you to book different room types in one booking (twin room and double room) also no accountability in the company for customers. As a customer if you have a problem, you call the hotel and your call is redirected to the reservation centre, then you are told to ring again to get hotel. 
It’s not right for customer.
You get a discount in all their properties, but you are treated like garbage in the hotels you visit. They will give you the worst rooms (view of trash cans) and literally in front of the elevator. So it’s not a great way to make you feel valued.

Money is shocking. But it is an easy job.

review_title: Beware! DO NOT FALL FOR THE LIES
pros: None. Cannot find a single good thing to share.
cons: This company does not care at all about the people that actually have to deal with the guests/customers. They treat them like crap! They offer remote work from home jobs which sound great at first...until you have to deal with a reservation system that is always breaking down. They don't train the staff long enough and expect so much from them-you would think that they're paying them at least $25 an hour to put up with so much! Wrong! For the measly $15 an hour they expect you to sell sell sell and dangle bonuses only to take them back due to poor productivity which is due to constant system issues. I have never in my life worked for such a horrific company. What's even worse? They just keep building new hotels on the backs of the staff members whose blood, sweat, tears and stress are in the foundations of those buildings and don't even consider paying them at least a decent pay of $20-$25 an hour. I hope that upper management reads this. This company is like a revolving door. Within the first few weeks of starting to work there at least 5 of my team members quit. Within the first few months almost the entire team is gone. One team member gave their 2 weeks notice and had to leave early due to the PTSD that comes a long with the job. And don't bother complaining to HR. They couldn't give a rats behind that you are stressed out because of THEM. They'll just hire another group and round and round it goes. Don't fall for the scam and don't stay at the hotels. You are paying for them to continue abusing their employees. So happy that I'm out of there.

review_title: Should have treated your employees better during COVID
pros: Great employee benefits! You get employee discounts on hotels and insurance benefits are fantastic.
cons:
- Favoritism in the workplace. People hired for positions/ given promotions based on favoritism or who they know, rather than work ethic. 
- When there are zero consequences for bad work ethic and zero (genuine) appreciation for good work ethic, there is ZERO motivation.
- Tardiness is unacceptable (understandably so, obviously), but managers need to learn to lead by example. Alot of the time managers / directors would come in late, take extended lunches, leave for "hair appointments", etc. - but still be clocked in the full shift. This makes for horrible moral.

review_title: Good company, poor control over GM quality
pros: Ability to grow career, with clearly understood time-in roles, to move to new position. Training is suppose to be possible, though that is only if the GM performs his/her role. Multiple markets and tiers of hotel management available to experience.
cons: GMs are not rotated, so the GMs make the hotel's their fiefdoms, which enables unprofessional treatment of team members, a lack of uniform processes between hotels, and over-extending their employees while they disappear for hours and take off for vacations repeatedly, leaving employees underwater. This was especially evident in the pandemic, where everyone else was pitching in, GMs continued to enjoy a great deal of flexibility, no time actively participating, and time off, returning to berate employees for what wasn't done, despite the lack of human resources, cut budgets and continued high-rate of physical, personnel and client problems . I'm aware of only 2 high performing GMs, in this large market, that everyone would love to work for. It has made multiple roles that report into the typical GM undesirable to stay in, even through each of my peers that have left, wanted to stay in Marriott. There is no good way to transfer, if your time in role is not done, or if the GM won't release you, because you are his/her workhorse. Interview the GM carefully, and ask to interview the staff. Also try to get to know staff at multiple hotels, before you choose to enter Marriott. Hotel management companies that thrive on results and excellence, might be a better fit. But, you could get some experience at Marriott first, to make you attractive: so don't write off Marriott, just have it in mind to use it as a stepping stone, if you do not happen to land with a good GM. If you have a good GM, support the GM, work to create an excellent work culture and find ways to improve the guest experience, processes and atmosphere.

pros: Work from home Managers are okay Downtime is available sometimes if there not enough calls You are able to go to the bathroom After 90 days you can request earlier shifts
cons: - The pay and what you deal with don’t match up -The software they use is outdated ,doesn’t alway work which means you lose sales -No pay after 4hrs if your having tech issues -training and actually on the calls do not match -you are given a discount to stay at properties however I found customers using the discount more than me - you can move up quickly however all customer service jobs remotely require you be on the phone including chat.Depending on the position will determine how often -The metrics are unrealistic. They want you to help the guest but control the call and do this under 10 minutes.and make a sale aka reservation - the guest can be rude and very entitled.You deal with this more with the higher tier members - No tech team.if a guest calls about app or websites issue you have to help them even though you was not train nor are tech savvy -back to back calls -taking days off is a struggle. They have a calendar and it tells you which days you can request or not -they do not acknowledge mental heath days -your not allow to have 2 days off in a row or take full weekends off.

pros:
Travel benefits are great, although getting steep discounts on hotel rooms has gotten a lot harder post-Covid. 
There's lots of areas to progress into and even try your hand out at things you never thought you'd be doing.
I have a bachelor's degree that's not in hospitality or even in business, but they really only care that I have a degree, not what's its in. That's been really nice because I've been able to take a job that was supposed to be temporary and make it a career.
cons:
The company has made a lot of changes over the last 3 years with the merger with Starwood and the changes continue daily. Sometimes it's hard to keep up with who reports to whom and who owns what. I feel like every week there's a new VP hired of a department I never knew existed (or didn't exist before this person was hired), but I feel like they're filling more VP positions and need to be working out the kinks waaaaay below that level. There's a lack of oversight in places and those places are hurting us. 
Communication can always be better between departments for changes that affect others.
Pay can always be better.
I do think they've lost sight of the Mr. Marriott quote that says "If you take care of your associates, your associates will take care of the guest and the guest will keep coming back". 2017 and 2018 forced a LOT of new technology that was broken down associates throats and has yet to fix it (its 2022)...

review_title: Marriott preaches values it can't uphold
pros: Good job stability- as they rarely fire anyone. Somewhat decent discounts at hotels, but you can rarely find a room for more than a couple of nights consecutively.
cons: Work with lots of inept people, especially management. Poor training all around. Forced to take breaks while working, tantamount to wage theft. Corporate does not understand working as an hourly employee, especially a server or bartender, and we are forced to take mandatory breaks or be made to stay after our shifts, or come in earlier to take an unpaid break. People across all departments describe working through unpaid breaks, all done under the guise of Marriott "caring" about each employee so that they have time to eat/ use the restroom, etc, but this is not what actually happens as there is frequently no coverage. A "working break" is supposed to be paid.

job_title: Food and Beverage Associate in Glasgow, Scotland
pros: If you're allowed the time to enjoy the benefits, they are quite good. A strong team feeling amongst the floor staff.
cons:
Senior Management and HR are far too close meaning there is no way of HR remaining a neutral party when issues arise.  There exists a 2-tier system of associates where 'upstairs' office workers are allowed to do things that the 'downstairs' floor workers would be reprimanded for.  This also contributes to an attitude from the office workers that their fellow associates are below them simply because they work in a front of house role.  It is also a major factor in creating the nasty and toxic work environment that trickles down from senior management.  People are promoted far too quickly and often left with minimal training to figure out entirely different job roles as they work. 
 The company tried to engage in "Fire and Re-Hire" during Covid-19 but are still left with a skill shortage as people moved on to different industries.

pros:
Benefits (after 90 days) 
Manager was nice
Staff and other agents friendly
cons:
For me it was an overall okay but not great experience.  I've worked for customer service for many years and this job was the most stressful out of all of them. I trained for a month, had a family emergency come up, and was told I would have to start my training all over again. I wouldn't have minded if I was one or two weeks in; but I was there for almost the full month and I would have to restart. But I think what made it an overall not good experience is the job wasn't worth the pay that they're giving you. Also having to work crazy hours until midnight doesn't help. If you wanted to change your hours you had to wait at least 90 days before than. On top of that having to wait 90 days before your benefits kicked in didn't help. I'm new to the state that I'm in and brought my own insurance until my job insurance came in. 
$15 an hour is nice until your bills start to add up and other employer's are hiring at a better rate. I learned this the hard way and to anyone who reads this know your worth because I'm not worth $15 and this job isn't worth it either.

Not worth the stress or mental headache

review_title: Leadership's priorities don't align with their slogan
pros:
Resort and Hotel discounts
Opportunity to work OT when offered
Bi-weekly income
cons:
Leadership doesn't align with the company's slogan: take care of your employees, they'll take care of your customers and the customers will keep coming back again and again.

It doesn't seem like the employees are well-taken care of with such low wages.

They do not offer night differential pay.

They offer discount hotel resort rates on your first hire date, yet they don't provide medical/dental benefits until 90 days later.

High turnover (especially in the call center department)

The tech support has poor follow-up skills. They close out tickets and enter them as tasks completed when the issue is pending.

They need to revamp the recruiting team so they can hire quality candidates, especially in the call center department.

pros: You can work from home
cons: The salary does not match what you have to deal with and put up with on a daily basis. They have a very HIGH turnover. There are only a few employees left from the original group of 30 I started working with. Almost all have left within a few short months, as the job is sooooo stressful. The biggest slap in the face is that they pride themselves on continually opening new hotels, which you have to read about daily, and multi million dollar renovations, but they can’t pay their employees a living wage. They have a lot to learn about doing right by their employees. They say that the employees come first, but they come last.

Management is lacking severely and training is on your own to figure out.

There are no opportunities to grow within the company unless you move to another city.

pros: Tepid employee discounts at Marriott properties. Decent 401k match.

They're forcing staff back into the new headquarters to justify all the money they spent on their new "fancy" downtown building, while the rest of our benefits shrink even though the return-to-office ship has already sailed. Laughable paid-time-off and company holidays. Incredibly bureaucratic inner-workings. No continuing-education reimbursement or initiatives. Flex schedule? Forget about it. No upward mobility for anyone who isn't already at the director level. Virtually nonexistent diversity and inclusion programs that aren't front-facing publicity stunts. I could keep going, but I don't think there is enough space here. Marriott is still operating like it's 1991.

pros: They make an honest effort to prepare their workers for the job, They provided new equipment that was simple to use. A desktop, Wi-Fi phone, headsets, ethernet cords. GREAT discounts on hotel rooms.
cons: 1. No Communication From Management PART A: You are expected to work EVERY holiday. No taking turns, not every other holiday, EVERY holiday The trainers claimed that this was explained upon hire. This was NOT explained upon hire. They kept repeating this lie even though EVERY associate in the hiring group agreed this was not mentioned upon hire. If you want a day off you have to compete with every single person, because the standard schedules are not honored during the holidays. The bidding for holidays is largely decided by seniority. That means they get every holiday off and you get nothing. I should at least be able to get ONE holiday off. In the first 90 days you don't even get bonus pay. How are you going to make me miss Christmas and Thanksgiving with my family and then disqualify me from holiday pay? If you don't live near your family then you have to give up on every seeing them. PART B: The first time I spoke to my manager was when I was resigning. I was there for a month and I had to repeatedly ask to get the name and email of my manager. By the time I got their name I was already ready to resign. There was no one to answer my questions. HR did not respond to my emails and my the trainers use all their time on the 5 people who need instructions on how to screw in a lightbulb. 2. Unprofessional coworkers/trainers Lots of gossip and meanspirited comments towards people not in the meeting rooms. I have NEVER reported anything to HR in my professional career. I considered doing it TWICE in the month I worked here. I mentioned the unprofessional environment as a reason for resignation. HR and management had ZERO interest in knowing what I was talking about. List of some minor and major things I witnessed. REALLLY distasteful statements made about the trainers and the workers not in the conference call. That I will not repeat because then this review would not get posted. A worker INSULTING and BERATING a coworker in a call with everyone in it. This was not interrupted or called out for being inappropriate. I would have fired this person on the spot. If I hadn't left the next day I would have reported them to HR and the trainers for allowing this person to bully their classmate. Individual talking about her sex life and how she hadn't gotten laid in 7 years in a work call with 20 people WHILE she was in office where management could hear. People chewing into microphones and not muting themselves. The trainers did not directly address this person they just made passive aggressive comments.

Their system is shockingly bad. Freezes constantly, doesn’t allow you to book different room types in one booking (twin room and double room) also no accountability in the company for customers. As a customer if you have a problem, you call the hotel and your call is redirected to the reservation centre, then you are told to ring again to get hotel. 
It’s not right for customer.
You get a discount in all their properties, but you are treated like garbage in the hotels you visit. They will give you the worst rooms (view of trash cans) and literally in front of the elevator. So it’s not a great way to make you feel valued.

Money is shocking. But it is an easy job.

review_title: Beware! DO NOT FALL FOR THE LIES
pros: None. Cannot find a single good thing to share.
cons: This company does not care at all about the people that actually have to deal with the guests/customers. They treat them like crap! They offer remote work from home jobs which sound great at first...until you have to deal with a reservation system that is always breaking down. They don't train the staff long enough and expect so much from them-you would think that they're paying them at least $25 an hour to put up with so much! Wrong! For the measly $15 an hour they expect you to sell sell sell and dangle bonuses only to take them back due to poor productivity which is due to constant system issues. I have never in my life worked for such a horrific company. What's even worse? They just keep building new hotels on the backs of the staff members whose blood, sweat, tears and stress are in the foundations of those buildings and don't even consider paying them at least a decent pay of $20-$25 an hour. I hope that upper management reads this. This company is like a revolving door. Within the first few weeks of starting to work there at least 5 of my team members quit. Within the first few months almost the entire team is gone. One team member gave their 2 weeks notice and had to leave early due to the PTSD that comes a long with the job. And don't bother complaining to HR. They couldn't give a rats behind that you are stressed out because of THEM. They'll just hire another group and round and round it goes. Don't fall for the scam and don't stay at the hotels. You are paying for them to continue abusing their employees. So happy that I'm out of there.

review_title: Should have treated your employees better during COVID
pros: Great employee benefits! You get employee discounts on hotels and insurance benefits are fantastic.
cons:
- Favoritism in the workplace. People hired for positions/ given promotions based on favoritism or who they know, rather than work ethic. 
- When there are zero consequences for bad work ethic and zero (genuine) appreciation for good work ethic, there is ZERO motivation.
- Tardiness is unacceptable (understandably so, obviously), but managers need to learn to lead by example. Alot of the time managers / directors would come in late, take extended lunches, leave for "hair appointments", etc. - but still be clocked in the full shift. This makes for horrible moral.

review_title: Good company, poor control over GM quality
pros: Ability to grow career, with clearly understood time-in roles, to move to new position. Training is suppose to be possible, though that is only if the GM performs his/her role. Multiple markets and tiers of hotel management available to experience.
cons: GMs are not rotated, so the GMs make the hotel's their fiefdoms, which enables unprofessional treatment of team members, a lack of uniform processes between hotels, and over-extending their employees while they disappear for hours and take off for vacations repeatedly, leaving employees underwater. This was especially evident in the pandemic, where everyone else was pitching in, GMs continued to enjoy a great deal of flexibility, no time actively participating, and time off, returning to berate employees for what wasn't done, despite the lack of human resources, cut budgets and continued high-rate of physical, personnel and client problems . I'm aware of only 2 high performing GMs, in this large market, that everyone would love to work for. It has made multiple roles that report into the typical GM undesirable to stay in, even through each of my peers that have left, wanted to stay in Marriott. There is no good way to transfer, if your time in role is not done, or if the GM won't release you, because you are his/her workhorse. Interview the GM carefully, and ask to interview the staff. Also try to get to know staff at multiple hotels, before you choose to enter Marriott. Hotel management companies that thrive on results and excellence, might be a better fit. But, you could get some experience at Marriott first, to make you attractive: so don't write off Marriott, just have it in mind to use it as a stepping stone, if you do not happen to land with a good GM. If you have a good GM, support the GM, work to create an excellent work culture and find ways to improve the guest experience, processes and atmosphere.

review_title: Great people, Interesting work, Bad quality of life
pros:
This review is for the law department at HQ in Bethesda, MD. 

*Smart, talented people in the law department and on the business side
*Interesting work. You will learn a lot and never be bored.
*Genuinely nice people in the law department
*Law department is valued by the Company. Will be a respected business partner.
*Opportunities to move over to the business side
cons:
* Horrible work/life balance. You will hear over and over the Company's mantra of "take good care of your associates and they will take good care of the guests and the guests will keep coming back." But it is just a slogan. The Company's actions do not back up its words.
*Not only will you work as hard or harder than you ever worked in a law firm, but the pay will be low. Even before the recent run up in law firm associate salaries, Marriott has for years paid below market. 
*Although the Company values the law department, that value does not extend to compensation or providing appropriate staffing to alleviate a crushing work load.
*Extremely limited opportunities to be promoted.

Join Marriott if you want to work with great, smart people and build your skills. Avoid it if you want to have work life/balance, be paid at market rates, or have a career track.
